frontmatter.title: Categorical composable cryptography

Sci.", VOLUME = 13242, PAGES = 161--183, PUBLISHER = "Springer, Cham", YEAR = 2022, ISBN = 978-3-030-99253-8, DOI = 10.1007/978-3-030-99253-8\_9, URL = "https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-030-99253-8_9", }

mainmatter.p: We formalize the simulation paradigm of cryptography in terms of category theory and show that protocols secure against abstract attacks form a symmetric monoidal category, thus giving an abstract model of composable security definitions in cryptography. Our model is able to incorporate computational security, set-up assumptions and various attack models such as colluding or independently acting subsets of adversaries in a modular, flexible fashion. We conclude by using string diagrams to rederive the security of the one- time pad, correctness of Diffie-Hellman key exchange and no-go results concerning the limits of bipartite and tripartite cryptography, ruling out e.g., composable commitments and broadcasting. On the way, we exhibit two categorical constructions of resource theories that might be of independent interest: one capturing resources shared among multiple parties and one capturing resource conversions that succeed asymptotically.
These are my notes from the paper Categorical Composable Cryptography.

An attack model A against a monoidal category consists of, for each morphism f, a class of morphisms A which is closed and factors horizontally and vertically. We write \xrightharpoonup{f'} _f for an attack f' \in A(f); commutative diagrams entail commutativity of both the target and the attack.

ul.li: if f' \in A(f) and g' \in A(g) and the composites exist, then g'f' \in A(gf);
if h \in A(gf) then h = g'f' for g' \in A(g) and f' \in A(f);
if f' \in A(f) and g' \in A(g), then f' \otimes g' \in A(f \otimes g);
if h \in A(f \otimes g) then h = h' \circ f' \otimes g' for f' \in A(f), g' \in A(g), and h' \in A(1_{ \text{cod} (f) \otimes \text{cod} (g)}).

Let D \xrightarrow{F} C \xrightarrow{R} Set be functors. A morphism (d, x) \xrightarrow{f} (d', x') in the category of elements \int RF is prefectly secure against an attack model A, or A-perfectly secure, if for any Fd \xrightharpoonup{a} _{Ff} z, there exists a Fd' \xrightharpoonup{a'} _{1_{Fd'}} z' such that (Ra)x = (Ra')x'.
In the model of categorical cryptography due to Broadbent & Karvonen, we can understand the categories and functors D \xrightarrow{F} C \xrightarrow{R} Set as follows.

ul.li: The category D is the space of "free" processes available to agents in the protocol.
The category C is the space of possible actions available to the protocol or to a threat model.
The functor F is "morally" an inclusion of D into C.
The elements of Rx are "states" on the system x \in C.
